{{Politics of Jersey}}

'''Politics of the [[Bailiwick]] of [[Jersey]]''' takes place in a framework of a [[parliamentary system|parliamentary]] [[representative democracy|representative democratic]] constitution.

As one of the [[Crown Dependencies]], Jersey is autonomous and self-governing, with its own independent [[Law of Jersey|legal]], administrative and [[Economy of Jersey#Taxation|fiscal]] systems.<ref>{{Cite book
  | last = House of Commons
  | first = Justice Committee
  | authorlink =
  | author2 =
  | title = Crown Dependencies
  | publisher = The Stationery Office
  | series =
  | volume = 8th Report of Session 2009–10
  | edition =
  | date = 23 March 2010
  | location = London
  | pages =
  | language =
  | url = https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmjust/56/56i.pdf
  | doi =
  | id =
  | isbn =978-0-215-55334-8
  | mr =
  | zbl =
  | jfm = }}</ref>

The legislature is the Assembly of the [[States of Jersey]].

[[Executive (government)|Executive]] powers are mainly exercised by a [[Chief Minister of Jersey|Chief Minister]] and nine ministers, known collectively as the [[Cabinet of Jersey|Council of Ministers]]. Other executive powers are exercised by the [[Connétable (Jersey and Guernsey)|Connétable]] and [[Parish Assembly (Jersey)|Parish Assembly]] in each of the twelve [[Parishes of Jersey|parishes]].

==The Crown==
[[File:Jour d'la Libéthâtion Jèrri 9 d'Mai 2011 038.jpg|thumb|The [[Lieutenant Governor of Jersey|Lieutenant Governor]] is the representative of head of state and the [[Bailiff (Channel Islands)|Bailiff]] is the civic head. Both are appointed by the Crown. Here the holders of the offices in 2011 are seen processing alongside on Liberation Day]]
[[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Elizabeth II]]'s traditional title as [[Head of State]] is [[Duke of Normandy]].<ref>{{Cite web
  | last = The official website of the British Monarchy
  | first =
  | authorlink =
  | coauthors =
  | title = Channel Islands
  | work =
  | publisher =
  | date =
  | url = http://www.royal.gov.uk/MonarchUK/QueenandCrowndependencies/ChannelIslands.aspx
  | format =
  | doi =
  | accessdate =22 August 2011 }}</ref> "[[The Crown]]" is defined by the Law Officers of the Crown as the "Crown in right of Jersey".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www5.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/R%20Attorney%20General%20Transcript%2020100702%20WM.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812153038/http://www5.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/R%20Attorney%20General%20Transcript%2020100702%20WM.pdf |archivedate=12 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Queen's representative and adviser in the island is the [[Lieutenant Governor of Jersey]]. He is a point of contact between Jersey ministers and the United Kingdom government and carries out executive functions in relation to immigration control, deportation, naturalisation and the issue of passports.<ref>{{Cite web| last =Office of the Lieutenant Governor| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Lieutenant-Governor| work =| publisher =| date =| url =http://www.jersey.com/governmenthouse/About/Pages/default.aspx| format =| doi =| accessdate =22 August 2011| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110812015723/http://www.jersey.com/governmenthouse/About/Pages/default.aspx| archivedate =12 August 2011| df =dmy-all}}</ref> Since 2011, the incumbent Lieutenant Governor has been Sir [[John McColl]].

The Crown (not the [[States of Jersey|government or parliament of Jersey]]) appoints the [[Lieutenant Governor of Jersey|Lieutenant Governor]], the [[Bailiff (Channel Islands)|Bailiff]], Deputy Bailiff, Attorney General and Solicitor General. In practice, the process of appointment involves a panel in Jersey which select a preferred candidate whose name is communicated to the UK [[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Justice]] for approval before a formal recommendation is made to the Queen.

==Constitution==

Jersey has an [[unwritten constitution]] arising from the [[Treaty of Paris (1259)]]. When Henry III and the King of France came to terms over the Duchy of Normandy, all lands except the [[Channel Islands]] recognised the [[suzerainty]] of the King of France. The Channel Islands however were never absorbed into the [[Kingdom of England]] by any Act of Union and exist as "peculiars of the Crown".

Campaigns for constitutional reform during the 19th century successfully called for: the replacement of lay [[Jurat]]s with professional judges in the [[Royal Court of Jersey|Royal Court]] to decide questions of law; the establishment of a Police Court (later known as the [[Courts of Jersey#Lower courts|Magistrate's Court]]); the creation of a [[Courts of Jersey#Lower courts|Petty Debts Court]]; a professional, salaried [[States of Jersey Police|police force]] for St Helier in addition to the [[Honorary Police]]; and the reform of "archaic procedure of the Royal Court for criminal trials".<ref>{{citation | first = J G | last = Le Quesne | contribution = The Development of Constitutional Autonomy during the Nineteenth Century | title = A Celebration of Autonomy: 1204–2004, 800 years of Channel Islands' Law | editor-first = Philip | editor-last = Bailhache | publisher = Jersey and Guernsey Law Review Ltd | place = St Helier | year = 2005| format = Book | isbn= 0-9535903-7-2}}</ref> In 1845, the elected office of deputy was created though this did little to redress the disparity of representation between the rural and urban [[Parishes of Jersey|parishes]]: in 1854 [[St Helier]] contained over half of the island's population, yet was able to elect only three out of the 14 deputies.<ref>{{Cite book
  | last = Le Hérissier
  | first = Roy
  | authorlink = 
  | author2 = 
  | title = The Development of the Government of Jersey 1771–1972
  | publisher = States of Jersey
  | series = 
  | volume = 
  | edition = 
  | year = 1972
  | location = St Helier, Jersey
  | pages = 88
  | language = 
  | url = 
  | doi = 
  | id = 
  | isbn =0-9501995-1-6
  | mr = 
  | zbl = 
  | jfm = }}</ref>

Two significant constitutional reforms took place during the 20th century. In 1946, the [[States of Jersey]] drew up plans for change following the [[German occupation of the Channel Islands|German Occupation]], which were examined by a Committee of the Privy Council.<ref>{{Cite book
  | last = Home Office
  | first =
  | authorlink =
  | author2 =
  | title = Report of the Committee of the Privy Council on Proposed Reforms in the Channel Islands
  | publisher = HMSO
  | series = Cmd 7074
  | volume =
  | edition =
  | date = March 1947
  | location =
  | pages =
  | language =
  | url =
  | doi =
  | id =
  | isbn =
  | mr =
  | zbl =
  | jfm = }}</ref> No change was made to the functions of the [[Bailiff (Channel Islands)|Bailiff]]. The twelve Jurats were removed from the assembly of the [[States of Jersey]] and replaced by twelve senators elected on an island-wide basis who would have no judicial functions. The twelve [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|Rector]]s also lost their place in the States assembly. No reforms were made to the role of the Deputies in the assembly. The second major reforms took place in December 2005, when the States of Jersey Law 2005 came into force. This created a system of ministerial government to replace the previous committee-based administration.<ref>Report of the Review Panel on the Machinery of Government in Jersey (December 2000) http://www.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/ID%20ClothierReport%20100331%20CC.pdf</ref>

* Loi (1804) au sujet des assemblées paroissiales<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f16%2f16.100_AssembleesParoissialesLoi1804_RevisedEdition_1January2011.htm | title = Loi (1804) au sujet des assemblées paroissiales | accessdate = 28 August 2011 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111003061343/http://www.jerseylaw.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2F16%2F16.100_AssembleesParoissialesLoi1804_RevisedEdition_1January2011.htm | archive-date = 3 October 2011 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>

Constitutional reforms continue to be debated in the island.

In 2009, the [[States of Jersey|States assembly]] rejected proposals by the Privileges and Procedures Committee to simplify the electoral system by keeping the 12 [[Connétable (Jersey and Guernsey)|Connétable]]s and introducing 37 deputies elected to six "super-constituencies".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.channelonline.tv/channelonline_jerseynews/displayarticle.asp?id=447730 |title=Constitutional reforms rejected – Jersey News from ITV Channel Television – channelonline.tv |work=channelonline.tv |year=2011 |accessdate=4 September 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322232914/http://www.channelonline.tv/channelonline_jerseynews/displayarticle.asp?id=447730 |archive-date=22 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2010, the States assembly agreed to holding elections for all seats on a single date and to cut the number of Senators from 12 to 8.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.channelonline.tv/channelonline_jerseynews/displayarticle.asp?id=491289 |title=Yes to General Elections – Jersey News from ITV Channel Television – channelonline.tv |work=channelonline.tv |year=2011 |accessdate=4 September 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322232921/http://www.channelonline.tv/channelonline_jerseynews/displayarticle.asp?id=491289 |archive-date=22 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

In December 2010, a committee chaired by [[Robert Carswell, Baron Carswell|Lord Carswell]] recommended changes to the role of the Bailiff—in particular that the Bailiff should cease to the presiding officer over the [[States of Jersey|States]] assembly.<ref>Andy Sibcy, 'Review says Bailiff should quit States', Jersey Evening Post, 6 December 2010 http://www.thisisjersey.com/2010/12/06/review-says-bailiff-should-quit-states/</ref>

Following widespread criticisms of the system of ministerial government introduced in December 2005, the [[States of Jersey|States assembly]] agreed in March 2011 to establish an independent electoral commission to review the make-up of the assembly and government.<ref>Minutes of the States of Jersey, 15 March 2011 http://www.statesassembly.gov.je; and see also {{cite web |url=http://www.channelonline.tv/channelonline_jerseynews/displayarticle.asp?id=493176 |title=States in a state? – Jersey News from ITV Channel Television – channelonline.tv |work=channelonline.tv |year=2011 |accessdate=4 September 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322232926/http://www.channelonline.tv/channelonline_jerseynews/displayarticle.asp?id=493176 |archive-date=22 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

In April 2011, Deputy Le Claire lodged au [[Greffier|Greffe]] a request for the Chief Minister to produce, for debate, a draft written "Constitution for Jersey";<ref name='P 52/2011'> {{cite journal | title = Constitution for Jersey | journal = States of Jersey | date = 5 April 2011 | first = Paul | last = Le Claire| id = | url = http://www.statesassembly.gov.je | accessdate =28 August 2011}}</ref> the [[States of Jersey|States assembly]] did not support this idea.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.statesassembly.gov.je | title = STATES OF JERSEY OFFICIAL REPORT WEDNESDAY, 4th MAY 2011 | accessdate =28 August 2011}}</ref>

=== International relations ===
{{See also|Jersey#Politics|l1=Jersey's international relations}}

The 1973 [[Kilbrandon Report]] stated that "In international law the United Kingdom Government is responsible for the Islands' international relations" and "also responsible for the defence of the Islands".<ref>{{Cite book
  | last = Royal Commission on the Constitution
  | first =
  | authorlink =
  | author2 =
  | title = Report of the Royal Commission on the Constitution 1963–1973
  | publisher = HMSO
  | series =

  | language =
  | url =
  | doi =
  | id =
  | isbn =
  | mr =
  | zbl =
  | jfm = }}</ref> The United Kingdom is responsible for Jersey's international relations as an aspect of the island's status as a [[Crown dependency]]. It is now normal practice for the UK to consult the [[Council of Ministers of Jersey|Jersey government]] and seek their consent before entering into [[treaty]] obligations affecting the island.

Since 2000, Jersey's "external personality" has developed, recognised in the preamble to the States of Jersey Law 2005 which refers to "an increasing need for Jersey to participate in matters of international affairs".<ref>http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce/htm/LawFiles/2005/l-08-2005.htm#_Toc88473872 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003103304/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fhtm%2FLawFiles%2F2005%2Fl-08-2005.htm |date=3 October 2011 }}</ref> In 2007, the [[Chief Minister of Jersey]] and the UK government agreed an "International Identity Framework", setting out the modern relationship between the United Kingdom and Jersey. The United Kingdom now issues "Letters of Entrustment" to the Jersey government, which delegate power to Jersey to negotiate international agreements on its own behalf and sign treaties in Jersey's own name rather than through the [[United Kingdom]]. This development was "strongly supported" by the [[House of Commons Justice Committee]] in its March 2010 report on the [[Crown Dependencies]].<ref>{{Cite book

  | mr =
  | zbl =
  | jfm = }}</ref> In January 2011 Senator [[Freddie Cohen]] was appointed as Assistant Chief Minister with responsibility for UK and International Relations (in effect, Jersey's first Foreign Minister).<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-12193265 |title=BBC News – Senator Freddie Cohen gets external relations role |first= |last=BBC|work=bbc.co.uk |accessdate=20 October 2011 |date=14 January 2011}}</ref> 
 
Jersey is neither a Member State nor an [[European Union Association Agreement|Associate Member]] of [[European Union]]. It does, however, have a relationship with the [[European Union|EU]] governed by Protocol 3 to the UK’s Treaty of Accession in 1972.<ref>[[Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union]], Article 355(5)(c) states "the Treaties shall apply to the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man only to the extent necessary to ensure the implementation of the arrangements for those islands set out in the Treaty concerning the accession of new Member States to the European Economic Community and to the European Atomic Energy Community signed on 22 January 1972".</ref>

In relation to the [[Council of Europe]], Jersey – as a territory the [[United Kingdom]] is responsible for in [[Public international law|international law]]– has been bound by the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] since the [[United Kingdom|UK]] acceded to the treaty in [[Human Rights Act 1998#Historical context|1951]]. The Human Rights (Jersey) Law 2000 makes [[European Convention on Human Rights|Convention rights]] part of [[Law of Jersey|Jersey law]] and is based closely on the United Kingdom's [[Human Rights Act 1998]].

During the 1980s, the question of Jersey making an annual contribution towards the United Kingdom's costs of defence and international representation undertaken on behalf of Jersey was raised. In 1987, the States of Jersey made an interim payment of £8 million while the matter was discussed.<ref>Minutes of the States of Jersey, 17 March 1987.</ref> The outcome of debates within the island was that the contribution should take the form of maintaining a [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] unit in Jersey. The Jersey Field Squadron (Militia), attached to the [[Royal Monmouthshire Royal Engineers]] (Militia), deploys individuals on operations in support of British Forces.<ref>{{cite hansard | title= Territorial Army | url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200809/ldhansrd/text/90707w0005.htm | house= House of Lords | date= 7 July 2009 | column= WA148}}</ref>

=== Separation debate ===
{{See also|Devolution in the United Kingdom|European microstates}}

The question of Jersey's independence has been discussed from time to time in the Assembly of the States of Jersey. In 1999, a member of the government said that 'Independence is an option open to the Island if the circumstances should justify this' but the government 'does not believe independence is appropriate in the present circumstances and does not see the circumstances arising in the foreseeable future when it would be appropriate'.<ref>Answer by Senate Pierre Horsfall to question by Deputy Paul Le Claire, Minutes of the States Assembly, 8 June 1999 http://www.statesassembly.gov.je/display_result.asp?url=\documents\minutes\35925-37231.htm{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In 2000, Senator [[Paul Le Claire]] called for a referendum on independence, a proposal which failed to win any significant support.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/g2/story/0,3604,362527,00.html |title=Land of milk and money |first= Paul|last=Kelso |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=1 September 2000 |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group|GMG]] |location=[[London, England|London]] |issn=0261-3077 |oclc=60623878 |accessdate=5 September 2011}}; {{cite web |url= http://www.moneymarketing.co.uk/news/jersey-institutions-reject-calls-for-independence/74483.article |title=Jersey institutions reject calls for independence|first= Joanne|last=O'Connell |work=moneymarketing.co.uk |year=2000 |accessdate=5 September 2011}}; {{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/jersey-may-split-from-uk-to-save-lowtax-status-710826.html |title=Jersey may split from UK to save low-tax status|first= Paul |last=Waugh |work=[[The Independent]] |date=28 August 2000 |publisher=[[Independent News & Media|INM]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0951-9467 |oclc=185201487 |accessdate=5 September 2011}}</ref> The Policy and Resources Committee of the [[States of Jersey]] established the Constitutional Review Group in July 2005, chaired by Sir [[Philip Bailhache]], with terms of reference 'to conduct a review and evaluation of the potential advantages and disadvantages for Jersey in seeking independence from the United Kingdom or other incremental change in the constitutional relationship, while retaining the Queen as Head of State'. The Group's ''Second Interim Report'' was presented to the States by the Council of Ministers in June 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statesassembly.gov.je/documents/reports/46527-24954-2762008.htm |title=Second Interim Report of the Constitution Review Group |publisher=Statesassembly.gov.je |accessdate=31 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511111106/http://www.statesassembly.gov.je/documents/reports/46527-24954-2762008.htm |archivedate=11 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The report concluded that 'Jersey is equipped to face the challenges of independence' but 'whether those steps should be taken is not within the remit of this paper'.

Proposals for Jersey independence have subsequently been discussed at an international conference held in Jersey, organised by the ''Jersey and Guernsey Law Review''.<ref>Editorial, 'Legal ideas of political importance', Jersey Evening Post, 21 September 2010 http://www.thisisjersey.com/2010/09/21/legal-ideas-of-political-importance/; Andy Sibcy, 'Sovereignty or dependency on agenda at conference', Jersey Evening Post, 17 September 2010 http://www.thisisjersey.com/2010/09/17/sovereignty-or-dependency-on-agenda-at-conference/; {{cite web |url=http://www.international-adviser.com/article/independence-debate-rears-head-in-channel-islands |title=Independence debate rears head in Channel Islands |first=Dan |last=Judge |work=international-adviser.com |year=2010 |accessdate=5 September 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110415193745/http://www.international-adviser.com/article/independence-debate-rears-head-in-channel-islands |archive-date=15 April 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The former Bailiff, Sir [[Philip Bailhache]] has called for changes to the Channel Islands' relationship with the United Kingdom government, arguing that 'at the very least, we should be ready for independence if we are placed in a position where that course was the only sensible option'.<ref>P Bailhache, 'One or two steps from sovereignty'  [2009] ''Jersey and Guernsey Law Review'' {{cite web |url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/oct09/JLR0910_Bailhache.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003102452/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/oct09/JLR0910_Bailhache.aspx |archivedate=3 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

In October 2012 the Council of Ministers issued a "Common policy for external relations"<ref name="External policy">{{cite web|title=COMMON POLICY FOR EXTERNAL RELATIONS|url=http://www.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/R%20Common%20policy%20for%20external%20relations%2020121122%20JS.pdf|publisher=States of Jersey|accessdate=8 December 2012}}</ref> that set out a number of principles for the conduct of external relations in accordance with existing undertakings and agreements. This document noted that Jersey "is a self-governing, democratic country with the power of self-determination" and "that it is not Government policy to seek independence from the United Kingdom, but rather to ensure that Jersey is prepared if it were in the best interests of Islanders to do so". On the basis of the established principles the Council of Ministers decided to "ensure that Jersey is prepared for external change that may affect the Island’s formal relationship with the United Kingdom and/or European Union".

==National Assembly – the States of Jersey==

[[File:States Building in St Helier Jersey.jpg|right|225px|thumb|The States building in St. Helier]] The [[Parliament|parliamentary body]] responsible for [[Law of Jersey#Sources of law|adopting legislation]] and scrutinising the [[Cabinet of Jersey|Council of Ministers]] is the Assembly of the [[States of Jersey]]. == National government – the Council of Ministers ==
[[File:Cyril le marquand house.jpg|thumb|left|Cyril Le Marquand House, St Helier, accommodating several States' departments]]
Historically, Jersey had a "committee-based system of administration embracing all public service functions and guaranteeing extensive involvement in policy-making for most members" of the Assembly of the [[States of Jersey]].<ref name="Morris 430"/>
The report of a review committee chaired by Sir [[Cecil Clothier]] criticised this system of government, finding it incapable of developing high-level strategy, efficient policy-coordination or effective political leadership.<ref>Report of the Review Panel on the Machinery of Government in Jersey (December 2000)</ref> The [https://web.archive.org/web/20111003103304/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fhtm%2FLawFiles%2F2005%2Fl-08-2005.htm States of Jersey Law 2005] introduced a ministerial system of government. Executive powers are now exercised by a [[Chief Minister of Jersey|Chief Minister]] and nine ministers, known collectively as the [[Cabinet of Jersey|Council of Ministers]] responsible to the States Assembly.

The Chief Minister is elected from amongst the elected members of the States. Ministers are then proposed both by the Chief Minister and any other elected member, the final decision being made by the States assembly.

There is no convention of [[Cabinet collective responsibility]] among members of the [[Council of Ministers of Jersey|Council of Ministers]]. The Council of Ministers reaches decisions by consensus and individual ministers retain the freedom to dissent from Council decisions in public and even present their own policy to the assembly of the [[States of Jersey|States]] in their capacity as a member of the assembly without having to resign as a minister.<ref name="Morris 430"/> Ministers are, however, bound by a ''Code of Conduct for Ministers'' approved in 2006.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.statesassembly.gov.je/documents/reports/37251-16065-1022006.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=26 August 2011 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805221314/http://www.statesassembly.gov.je/documents/reports/37251-16065-1022006.htm |archive-date=5 August 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, this may change as recently the Jersey Evening Post reported "MINISTERS will be bound by collective responsibility and the Chief Minister will have the power to fire his ministerial colleagues after a package of changes to the way Jersey’s government is run were approved." <ref>http://jerseyeveningpost.com/news/2014/05/21/members-no-longer-allowed-to-openly-disagree/</ref>

The overall direction of government as agreed by the Council of Ministers is published periodically as a "strategic plan", the current one being the ''States of Jersey Strategic Plan 2009–2014''.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gov.je/Government/Pages/StatesReports.aspx?ReportID=237 |title=States of Jersey Strategic Plan 2009–2014 |first= |last= Council of Ministers|work=gov.je |year=2011 |accessdate=5 September 2011}}</ref> These plans are debated and approved by the assembly of the [[States of Jersey]] and translated into action by a series of business plans for each department.

Several departments, each headed by a minister, are responsible for developing policy within the framework of the strategic plan and for implementing services. They include: the Chief Minister's Department; Economic Development; Education, Sport and Culture; Health and Social Services; Home Affairs; Housing; Environment; Social Security; Transport and Technical Services; and Treasury and Resources.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gov.je/GOVERNMENT/DEPARTMENTS/Pages/default.aspx |title=Government departments |first= |last= States of Jersey |work=gov.je |year=2011 |accessdate=4 September 2011}}</ref>

==Political parties==
In 2000, the Clothier report noted that "over the centuries Jersey has had many parties, by which one means only a coming together of like minds to achieve a particular objective. Once achieved, the binding purpose has disappeared and the group pursuing it has dissolved. Such a grouping is not a true political party because it lacks the cement of a common philosophy of government, having only a narrow objective to hold it together until the objective is either attained or lost".<ref>{{cite book | last1 = States of Jersey | title = Report of the Review Panel on the Machinery of Government in Jersey | publisher = States of Jersey | date = December 2000 | location = St Helier, Jersey | pages = para 4.10 }}</ref> Various [[List of political parties in Jersey|parties]] have been formed over the years in Jersey, but since the 1950s the majority of candidates have stood for election [[Independent (politician)|unaffiliated]] to any political party.

=== 18th century ===

Historically, two parties dominated Jersey politics. Originating in the 1770s, the ''Jeannot party'' formed around the radical lawyer and [[Connétable (Jersey and Guernsey)|Connétable]], Jean Dumaresq, who opposed the cabal of [[Jurat]]s who surrounded Lieutenant-[[Bailiff (Channel Islands)|Bailiff]] Charles Lemprière (whose supporters became known as the ''Charlot party''). The Jeannots rapidly adopted the nickname of ''Magots'' ([[cheese mites]]) after their opponents boasted of aiming to crush them like [[mites]].<ref>{{Cite book
  | last = Le Hérissier
  | first = Roy

=== 19th century ===
[[File:Bread riots in St Helier Jersey Channel Islands 1847.jpg|thumb|Bread riots in St Helier, 1847]]The Charlots and Magots contested power at elections until in 1819 the progressive Magots adopted the [[rose]] as their emblem, while the conservative Charlots wore [[Bay laurel|laurel]] leaves. The symbolism soon became entrenched to the extent that gardens displayed their owners' allegiances, and [[pink]] or [[green]] paintwork also showed political sympathies. Still today in Jersey, the presence of established laurels or rose gardens in old houses gives a clue to the past party adherence of former owners, and the chair of the Constable of [[Saint Helier]] in the Assembly Room of the Parish Hall still sports the carved roses of a former incumbent.

In order to help control voting in Jersey, it was not unknown for citizens to find themselves taken and stranded on the [[Écréhous]] until after voting had taken place.<ref>{{cite book |first=Glynis |last=Cooper |title=Foul Deeds and Suspicious Deaths in Jersey |publisher=Casemate Publishers, 2008 |ISBN=9781845630683}}</ref>{{rp|72}} By the time of the introduction of the secret ballot in 1891, party politics had waned.

''Blues'' and ''Reds'' contested local elections into the 1920s, but Islandwide party politics lay dormant until the post-Occupation elections under the new Constitution of 1948.

=== After the Occupation ===
[[File:Philip-Le-Feuvre-1948.jpg|thumb|left|Senator Philip Le Feuvre topped the poll in 1948 on a platform of implementing Social Security]]The first election under the new constitution saw a struggle for dominance between the [[Jersey Democratic Movement]] and the [[Jersey Progressive Party]], led by [[Cyril Le Marquand]]. Having achieved the political reforms it advocated the Progressive Party soon folded as an organisation, while the Democratic Movement, incorporating the tiny [[Communist Party of Jersey]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guernsey-society.org.uk/donkipedia/index.php5?title=Norman_Le_Brocq |title=Norman Le Brocq – Donkipedia |first= |last=Anon |work=guernsey-society.org.uk |year=2011 |accessdate=4 September 2011 }}; {{cite web |url= http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/news/content/view/full/13877 |title= Channel Islands reds / Features / Home – Morning Star |first= Peter |last= Tabb |work= morningstaronline.co.uk |year= 2011 |accessdate= 4 September 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120601034715/http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/news/content/view/full/13877 |archive-date= 1 June 2012 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> continued in existence as a campaigning social movement until the late 20th century.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thisisjersey.com/2008/09/26/party-time-in-december-45/ |title=Party time in December '45 |first= |last=Anon |work=thisisjersey.com |year=2011 |accessdate=4 September 2011}}</ref>

=== The 1980s ===
The [[Jersey Green Party]] succeeded in having candidates elected in the 1980s.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}  There were difficulties in maintaining a successful party structure in a consensus government system.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}  Former Senator [[Stuart Syvret]] was often reported to be a Green and represents the Jersey Greens in the [[Green Islands Network]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}

=== After the 2005 constitutional reforms ===
The prospect of [[Council of Ministers of Jersey|ministerial government]] and the creation of an executive and opposition, led to the formation of two political parties – the [[Jersey Democratic Alliance]] and the [[Centre Party (Jersey)|Centre Party]] – in preparation for the [[Jersey general election, 2005|2005 elections]]. A group called "Elect Jersey 2005" worked to assist some independent candidates prepare for the elections.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Top-level meeting on 2005 election | journal = Jersey Evening Post | date = 16 June 2005 | first = Harry | last = McRandle| id = | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/2005/06/16/top-level-meeting-on-2005-election/ | accessdate =29 August 2011}}; {{cite journal | title = Island 'is not ready for party politics' | journal = Jersey Evening Post | date = 17 June 2005 | first = Harry | last = McRandle| id = | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/2005/06/17/island-is-not-ready-for-party-politics/ | accessdate =29 August 2011}}; {{cite journal | title = Panels are set up to help independents | journal = Jersey Evening Post | date = 9 August 2005| id = | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/2005/08/09/panels-are-set-up-to-help-independents/ | accessdate =29 August 2011}}</ref> None of the party-affiliated candidates was successful in the October senatorial elections;<ref>{{cite journal | title = Poll triump for Senator Syvret and independent new commers | journal = Jersey Evening Post | date = 20 October 2005 | first = Anthony | last = Lewis| id = | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/2005/10/20/poll-triumph-for-senator-syvret-and-independent-newcomers/ | accessdate =29 August 2011}}</ref> three [[Jersey Democratic Alliance|JDA]] members standing as independents were elected as deputies in November 2005 along with two members of the [[Centre Party (Jersey)|Centre Party]] who had similarly stood as independents.<ref>{{cite journal | title = The party's over for the Democratic Alliance | journal = Jersey Evening Post | date = 8 May 2006 | first = Ben | last = Querée| id = | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/2006/05/08/the-partys-over-for-the-democratic-alliance/ | accessdate =29 August 2011}}</ref>  The Centre Party was wound up in 2007.

In 2008, legislation was passed to require registration of political parties who wished to endorse candidates for election as a senator, deputy or [[Connétable (Jersey and Guernsey)|Connétable]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.jerseylaw.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2F16%2F16.555_PoliticalParties%28Registration%29Law2008_RevisedEdition_1January2009.htm | title = Political Parties (Registration)(Jersey) Law 2008 | accessdate = 29 August 2011 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120331180452/http://www.jerseylaw.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2F16%2F16.555_PoliticalParties(Registration)Law2008_RevisedEdition_1January2009.htm | archive-date = 31 March 2012 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>

In the [[Jersey general election, 2008|2008 elections]] for senators, the [[Jersey Democratic Alliance|JDA]] fielded two candidates, two candidates stood as members of the campaign group  "Jersey 2020" (focusing on environmental issues) and two for "Time4Change/Reform": none was successful.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/election/senators/ | title = Jersey Evening Post Election 2008: senators | accessdate =29 August 2011}}</ref> In the subsequent deputies' elections, four [[Jersey Democratic Alliance|JDA]] candidates were successful,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/election/deputies/st-helier-no-2/ | title = Jersey Evening Post Election 2008: St Helier No. 2 | accessdate =29 August 2011}}; {{cite web | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/election/deputies/st-helier-no-1/ | title = Jersey Evening Post Election 2008: St Helier No. 1 | accessdate =29 August 2011}}</ref> but three of them subsequently left the party and continued to sit as independents.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Is the party over? | journal = Jersey Evening Post | date = 16 August 2010 | first = Ben | last = Querée| id = | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/2010/08/16/is-the-party-over/ | accessdate =29 August 2011}}</ref> In August 2011, the [[Jersey Democratic Alliance|JDA]] announced that party members would stand only as independents in the [[Jersey general election, 2011|October 2011]] elections.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Jersey Democratic Alliance not standing in elections | journal = BBC News Jersey | date = 31 August 2011| id = | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-14732423 | accessdate =1 September 2011}} and {{cite journal | title = Last member of the JDA says he'll stand as independent | journal = Jersey Evening Post | date = 3 September 2011 | first = Ben | last = Querée | pages = 9| id = | type = Print }}</ref> A branch of the '[[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] Abroad' was formed in the island in November 2011.<ref>{{cite news | first = Anon | title = Lib Dem group to set up in Jersey | date = 6 December 2011 | url = http://www.thisisjersey.com/news/2011/12/06/lib-dem-group-to-set-up-in-jersey/ | work = This is Jersey | accessdate =4 January 2012}}; {{cite news | first = Anon | title = Jersey group to open Liberal Democrat branch | date = 29 November 2011 | publisher = BBC | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-15936982 | work = BBC News Jersey | accessdate =4 January 2012}}</ref>

On 4 July 2014, [[Reform Jersey]] became Jersey's only political party when it was registered in the Royal Court.<ref>http://tomgruchy.blogspot.co.uk/2014/07/reform-jersey-first-political-party.html</ref> The party contested the 2014 general election where 3 of their 8 candidates were elected.<ref>http://www.vote.je</ref>

==Local government==
{{main|Parish Assembly (Jersey)}}
[[File:Jersey.png|right|400px|Map of the parishes of Jersey]]
Jersey is divided into twelve administrative districts known as [[Parishes of Jersey|parishes]]. All have access to the sea and are named after the saints to whom their ancient parish churches are dedicated.

The [[parishes of Jersey]] are further divided into ''[[vingtaine]]s'' (or, in St. Ouen, ''cueillettes''), divisions which are historic and nowadays mostly used for purposes of electoral constituency in municipal elections. These elections are held to elect the members of the Parish [[Parishes of Jersey#Municipal structure|municipality]]. Each parish as an [[Honorary Police]] force of elected, unpaid civilians who exercise police and prosecution powers.

== Jersey Politicians ==
{{Main| List of politicians in Jersey}}

==Elections in Jersey==
{{main|Elections in Jersey}}

Elections for Senators and Deputies occur at fixed four-yearly intervals, historically in October.<ref>States of Jersey Law 2005, Part 2 http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce/htm/LawFiles/2005/l-08-2005.htm#_Toc88473875 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003103304/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fhtm%2FLawFiles%2F2005%2Fl-08-2005.htm |date=3 October 2011 }} as amended by the States of Jersey (Miscellaneous Provisions) Law 2011</ref> From 2018, elections will be held in May every fourth year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.jerseylaw.je/laws/revised/Pages/16.800.aspx#_Toc466548623 |title=STATES OF JERSEY LAW 2005 |website=jerseylaw.je}}</ref>

At a [[Parishes of Jersey|local level]], the [[Connétable (Jersey and Guernsey)|Connétable]]s (or 'constables') are elected for four years. Other posts in parish municipalities vary in length from one to three years and elections take place at a [[Parish Assembly Jersey|Parish Assembly]] on a majority basis. It has been some time since parties contested elections at this level, other than for the position of [[Connétable (Jersey and Guernsey)|Connétable]] who uniquely has a role in both the [[States of Jersey|national assembly]] and in local government.

==Political pressure groups==
Jersey, as a polity predominated by independents has always had a number of [[Jersey Pressure Groups|pressure group]]s. Many ad-hoc lobby groups form in response to a single issue and then dissolve once the concerns have been dealt with. However, there are a number of pressure groups actively working to influence government decisions on a number of issues. For example, in 2012 the National Trust engaged in pressure campaign against development of the Plemont headland. The Trust was supported by the majority of the islands senior politicians, including the Chief Minister, but a proposition made in the States of Jersey for the States to compulsorily purchase the headland and sell it to the Trust was defeated in a vote on 13/12/12. The outcome of the vote was 24 in favour of acquisition, 25 against, with one absent and one declaring an interest.

The economy of [[Jersey]] is largely driven by international [[financial services]] and legal services, which accounted for 40.5% of total [[Gross value added|GVA]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.je/Government/Pages/StatesReports.aspx?ReportID=719 |title=Jersey Gross Value Added (GVA)and Gross National Income (GNI) 2010 |publisher=Gov.je |date= |accessdate=2012-10-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402114256/http://www.gov.je/Government/Pages/StatesReports.aspx?ReportID=719 |archivedate=2 April 2015}}</ref>  Other sectors include [[construction]], [[retail]], [[agriculture]], [[tourism]] and [[telecommunications]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.je/NR/rdonlyres/D9B4136B-D779-452D-B7BF-90D226F9CA18/0/GVAandGNI2007.pdf |title=Jersey Gross Value Added (GVA) and Gross National Income (GNI) 2007 |publisher=Gov.je }}{{dead link|date=February 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

In 2008 Jersey’s [[gross national income]] per capita was among the highest in the
world.<ref name="JED 2008">{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.je/NR/rdonlyres/8A7191DC-9CF9-4330-9D7B-78E473A2A248/0/JED2008.pdf |title=JED 2008 |publisher=Gov.je }}{{dead link|date=February 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

In 2011 the island's economy, as measured by [[Gross value added|GVA]], declined by 1% to £3.6 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.je/GOVERNMENT/JERSEYWORLD/STATISTICSUNIT/BUSINESSECONOMY/Pages/GVAandGNI.aspx |title=GVA and GNI |publisher=Gov.je |date=2012-09-27 |accessdate=2013-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130323023113/https://www.gov.je/Government/JerseyWorld/StatisticsUnit/BusinessEconomy/Pages/GVAandGNI.aspx |archivedate=2013-03-23 |df= }}</ref>

==Financial and legal services==

[[Image:Banque Rouoyale d'Êcosse, Saint Hélyi, Jèrri 4.jpg|thumb|left|Royal Bank of Scotland building.]]
Jersey based financial organisations provide services to customers worldwide.  In June 2008 it was reported that 12,070 people were employed full-time, within this sector.<ref name="Manpower by Sector">{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.je/NR/rdonlyres/6E822EC5-5C29-4637-BAE0-C581443C6EAC/0/LabourMarketPrivateManpowerBySector.xls |title=Manpower by Sector |publisher=Gov.je}} {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) is a major employer with some 900 staff employed in Jersey, as of March 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/jersey/7923617.stm |title=RBSI in Jersey |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-03-04 |accessdate=2012-10-12}}</ref>

The finance sector profits rose to about £1.5 billion in 2007,
representing a real-term increase of 12% on 2006.<ref name="JED 2008"/>

[[File:JFSC.jpg|thumb|right|Logo of the financial regulator ''Jersey Financial Services Commission'']]

Jersey is one of the top worldwide [[Offshore financial center]]s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zyen.com/GFCI/GFCI%208.pdf|title=The Global Financial Centres Index 8 |publisher=[[Z/Yen]] |year=2010}}</ref> It is described by some as a [[tax haven]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Nick Mathiason, business correspondent |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/nov/04/4 |title=Jersey is a tax haven |publisher=Guardian |date= 2007-11-03|accessdate=2014-12-08 |location=London}}</ref> It attracts deposits from customers outside of the island, seeking the advantages such places offer, like reduced tax burdens. Its taxation laws have been widely criticised by various people and groups,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.taxresearch.org.uk/Blog/category/jersey/ |title=Tax Research UK » Jersey |publisher=Taxresearch.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-03-31}}</ref> however the former [[Chief Minister of Jersey]], [[Terry Le Sueur]], has countered these criticisms, saying that "Jersey [is] among cooperative finance centres".<ref>{{cite news|last=Molony |first=James |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/03/04/uk-jersey-transparency-interview-sb-idUKTRE5235QJ20090304 |title=Jersey among cooperative finance centres |publisher=Reuters.com |date=2009-03-04 |accessdate=2012-10-12}}</ref> And in September 2013 the UK Prime Minister, David Cameron, said it was not fair any longer to refer to any of the overseas territories or Crown dependencies as tax havens, as they have taken action to make sure that they have fair and open tax systems.[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201314/cmhansrd/cm130909/debtext/130909-0001.htm#13090914000005 House of Commons Hansard 9 Sept 2013] Its [[Data Protection (Jersey) Law|information privacy law]] also provides exemptions that other European countries do not, for example in the way [[Trusts]] do not have to disclose as much information to [[Beneficiary (trust)|Benficiaries]] about use of their personal data as is normally required under such laws.<ref name=mondaq1>[http://www.mondaq.com/article.asp?articleid=63832 Jersey: Data Protection In Jersey And Other Offshore Jurisdictions] 23 July 2008 Article by Wendy Benjamin, mondaq.com, retr 2012 Sep 14</ref>

Jersey's finance industry featured in a [[BBC]] [[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]] [[Documentary film|documentary]], titled "Tax me if you can",<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbcworldnews.com/Pages/Programme.aspx?id=257 |title=Tax me if you can |publisher=Bbcworldnews.com |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2012-10-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503120042/http://www.bbcworldnews.com/Pages/Programme.aspx?id=257 |archive-date=2009-05-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> first broadcast on 2 February 2009.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00hd3x0 |title=BBC One - Panorama, Tax Me if You Can |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2009-02-10 |accessdate=2013-03-31}}</ref>

On 4 February 2009 Jersey Finance officially announced its intention to open a new representative office in London.<ref>[http://www.jerseyfinance.je/content/3476/index.html Jersey Finance London Office] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305033211/http://www.jerseyfinance.je/content/3476/index.html |date=March 5, 2009 }}</ref>

At the end of 2008 deposits in [[Jersey]] banks totalled £206 billion, down £6.2 billion from £212.3 billion at the start of the year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerseyfinance.je/_support/uploadedFiles/Quarterly%20report%20for%20period%20ended%2031st%20December%202008.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320142518/http://www.jerseyfinance.je/_support/uploadedFiles/Quarterly%20report%20for%20period%20ended%2031st%20December%202008.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-20 |df= }}</ref>

The first regulated [[Bitcoin]] fund was established in Jersey in July 2014, with the approval of the Jersey Financial Services Commission, after island leaders expressed a desire for Jersey to become a global center for digital currencies. At the time of the establishment of the fund by a Jersey-based hedge fund company, Bitcoin was already being accepted by some local businesses.<ref name="BitcoinJersey">{{cite news|title=Jersey approve Bitcoin fund launch on island|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-jersey-28247796|accessdate=10 July 2014|publisher=''BBC news''}}</ref>

==Construction==

Construction represented 5.2% of [[Gross value added|GVA]] during 2007. In June 2008 it was reported that 4,980 people were employed full-time in the construction and quarrying sector.<ref name="Manpower by Sector"/>

[[St. Helier]], and the Waterfront area in particular, has seen much redevelopment during the early 21st century, with several projects in planning or under-construction during 2009. Developments include a leisure complex,<ref>[http://www.jerseywaterfront.je/content/12/index.html Leisure complex] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090311005356/http://www.jerseywaterfront.je/content/12/index.html |date=March 11, 2009 }}</ref> the Radisson hotel,<ref>[http://www.jerseywaterfront.je/content/15/index.html Radisson Hotel] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090311004515/http://www.jerseywaterfront.je/content/15/index.html |date=March 11, 2009 }}</ref> and a new central bus station - Liberation Station. As of 2009 there are plans to sink the A1 road, to provide building sites above it for offices,<ref>[http://www.jerseywaterfront.je/content/17/index.html Esplanade Quarter] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201001558/http://www.jerseywaterfront.je/content/17/index.html |date=February 1, 2009 }}</ref> possibly for financial companies.

Construction grew by 8% over the period 2006 to 2007.<ref name="JED 2008"/>

==Retail and wholesale==

As of June 2008 there were 6,610 persons in full-time employment within Jersey's wholesale and retail trades.<ref name="Manpower by Sector"/>

Retail and wholesale grew by around 5% during 2007.<ref name="JED 2008"/>

Sandpiper C.I. Limited operate a chain of stores in Jersey, their franchises include well-known names, such as [[Marks & Spencer]], Iceland, and [[Costa Coffee]].<ref>[http://www.sandpiperci.com/index.html Sandpiper CI Ltd.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228144324/http://www.sandpiperci.com/index.html |date=2009-02-28 }}</ref>

A number of online retailers, and [[fulfillment house]]s operate from the Channel Islands, including Jersey, supplying a variety of low-value goods such as CDs, DVDs, video games, and gadgets. Residents of the EU were choosing to order goods from Jersey, so as to benefit from a tax relief known as [[Low-value consignment relief]] (LVCR). UK residents, in particular, were taking advantage of this situation.

A local company, [[play.com]] grew substantially during the time that LVCR applied to Jersey. Notably, [[Amazon.com|Amazon UK]] also took advantage of this by dispatching some low-value items from Jersey.

In April 2012 the UK Government made law changes to prevent the Channel Islands continued exploitation of LVCR, meaning that UK residents would have to pay the full [[VAT]] amount on items imported from the Channel Islands.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-17563620 Channel Islands' VAT 'loophole' LVCR ends]</ref> Some goods are still sold and distributed from Jersey, despite these changes.

==Agriculture==

Potatoes, cauliflower, tomatoes, and flowers are important export crops, shipped mostly to the [[United Kingdom]]. The [[Jersey cattle|Jersey breed of dairy cattle]] is known worldwide and represents an important export income earner. Milk products go to the UK and other [[European Union|EU]] countries.

As of 2009 the [[Jersey Royal potato]] is the biggest crop export.

==Tourism==

[[Image:Hotel de france.JPG|thumb|Hotel de France]]
Jersey saw a boom in tourism during the post-World War II years. This boom has been winding down since the late-1980s. Many of the larger hotels, which were constructed during the boom, have now been demolished.

Visitors to the island arrive either by sea at [[Saint Helier]], or by air at [[Jersey Airport]]. These routes are subsidised by the [[States of Jersey]].<ref>[http://www.thisisjersey.com/2007/05/15/airline-to-begin-paris-service/ Airline subsidies]</ref> Exact figures for subsidies are not in the public domain.

Visitor length of stays have reduced from an average of 5.7 nights, in 1997, to 4.3 nights, in 2010.<ref>[http://www.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/ID%20JerseyInFigures2010%2020110427%20SU.pdf Jersey in Figures 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105120915/http://www.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/ID%20JerseyInFigures2010%2020110427%20SU.pdf |date=2011-11-05 }}</ref>

Most [[tourist attraction]]s are operated by private companies, including companies owned, or funded by the States of Jersey. [[Elizabeth Castle]], for example, is controlled by [[Jersey Heritage]]. Some other attractions are owned by the [[National Trust for Jersey]].

In 2011 visitor numbers rose by 0.6%, with a notable increase in visitors from Germany, and France. It was reported that tourist and business visitors spent a total of £242m while on the island.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-17310983 Small rise in visitors to Jersey but they are spending more]</ref>

==Transport, storage and communication==
{{see also|Transport in Jersey}}

This sector accounted for 4% of [[Gross value added|GVA]] during 2007.<ref name="JED 2008"/>

Most of the telecoms infrastructure is owned by [[Jersey Telecom]].

In 2008, most goods imported and exported were transported by Huelin-Renouf,<ref>[http://www.huelin-renouf.co.uk/ Huelin-Renouf Shipping]</ref> Condor Logistics,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.condorlogistics.co.uk/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031226184257/http://www.condorlogistics.co.uk/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2003-12-26 |title=Default Parallels Plesk Panel Page |publisher=Condorlogistics.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-03-31 }}</ref> and other smaller operators, via either [[Saint Helier]] harbour, or [[Jersey Airport]].

During the period 1984 to 1994, [[British Channel Island Ferries]] were responsible for much shipping to and from the [[United Kingdom]].

==Stock exchange==
Jersey shares [[The International Stock Exchange]] (TISE) with [[Guernsey]], where it is based.<ref>[http://www.cisx.com/content.php?pageid=273 Channel Islands Stock Exchange]</ref>

==Seasonal workers==
The workforce in Jersey tends to increase during the summer months, with around 3,500 more people employed in the summer of 2008 than in the winter of 2007.<ref name="JED 2008"/> These seasonal workers are mostly employed in agriculture, hotels, restaurants and bars.

==Traditional and historical economy==

===Agriculture===
Until the 19th century, [[cider]] was the largest agricultural export with up to a quarter of the agricultural land given over to orchards. In 1839 for example, {{convert|268199|impgal|L}} of cider were exported from [[Jersey]] to England alone,<ref>''Balleine's History of Jersey'', {{ISBN|1-86077-065-7}}</ref> but by 1870 exports from Jersey had slumped to {{convert|4632|impgal|L}}.<ref>''The Triumph of the Country'', Kelleher, Jersey 1994, {{ISBN|0-9518162-4-1}}</ref> Beer had replaced cider as a fashionable drink in the main export markets, and even the home market had switched to beer as the population became more urban. Potatoes overtook cider as the most important crop in Jersey in the 1840s. Small-scale cider production on farms for domestic consumption, particularly by seasonal workers from Brittany and mainland Normandy, was maintained, but by the mid-20th century production dwindled until only eight farms were producing cider for their own consumption in 1983.<ref>Jersey Society in London, Bulletin, 1983</ref> The number of orchards had been reduced to such a level that the destruction of trees in the Great Storm of 1987 demonstrated how close the Islands had come to losing many of its traditional cider apple varieties. A concerted effort was made to identify and preserve surviving varieties and new orchards were planted. As part of diversification, farmers have moved into commercial cider production, and the cider tradition is celebrated and marketed as a heritage experience.

===Textiles===
The [[knitting]] of woollen garments was a thriving industry for Jersey during the 17th and 18th centuries.<ref>[http://www.vam.ac.uk/collections/fashion/features/knitting/regional/index.html Regional Knitting in the British Isles and Ireland] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027131353/http://www.vam.ac.uk/collections/fashion/features/knitting/regional/index.html |date=October 27, 2007 }}</ref>

===Ship building===
Jersey was the 4th largest ship building area in the 19th century [[British Isles]]. See [[History of Jersey]].

==Historical exchange rates==
Jersey pounds per US dollar - 0.55 (2005), 0.6981 (January 2002), 0.6944 (2001), 0.6596 (2000), 0.6180 (1999), 0.6037 (1998), 0.6106 (1997); the Jersey pound is at par with the British pound.

==Taxation==
Until the twentieth century, the States relied on indirect taxation to finance the administration of Jersey. The levying of ''impôts'' (duties) was in the hands of the Assembly of Governor, Bailiff and Jurats until 1921 when that body's tax raising powers were transferred to the Assembly of the States, leaving the Assembly of Governor, Bailiff and Jurats to serve simply as licensing bench for the sale of alcohol. The Income Tax Law of 1928 introducing [[income tax]] was the first law drafted entirely in English. Income tax has been levied at a [[Flat tax|flat rate]] of 20% for decades.

Historically, no [[Value added tax|VAT]] was levied in Jersey, with the result that luxury goods have often been cheaper than in the UK or in France. This provided an incentive for tourism from neighbouring countries. The absence of VAT also led to the growth of a [[Fulfillment house|fulfilment]] industry, whereby low-value luxury items, such as videos, lingerie and contact lenses are exported in a manner [[Value-Added-Tax-free imports from the Channel Islands|avoiding VAT on arrival]], thus undercutting local prices on the same products. In 2005 the States of Jersey announced limits on licences granted to non-resident companies trading in this way. The States of Jersey introduced a [[Value added tax|goods and services tax]] (GST) in 2008. Although this is a form of VAT, it has been charged at a much lower rate than UK or French VAT, and as such Jersey's fulfilment industry continues.

The strategy for introducing the new GST tax was to fill a 'black hole' in the budget that was created by the introduction of a new 0/10 tax that replaced the old tax system that previously exempted foreign investors from corporation tax and levied a 20% rate on Jersey residents. The new 0/10 tax exempts all businesses except those in financial services from having to pay any corporation tax (0%), while leaving the financial services to pay a low tax rate (10%). The income generated from the new 0/10 tax proposal will not be equal to the revenue of the original tax system and this leaves Jersey with a deficit in its budget of several million pounds.

To fill the deficit created by the changes made to Jersey's tax structure, the States of Jersey introduced GST.
GST is added to most goods and services, which has raised the cost of living. The people hit the hardest by the new GST will be the people on the lowest incomes, however, to try to prevent islanders living below the poverty line, the States of Jersey introduced an Income Support service in January 2008.

It is arguable that the people who benefit from Jersey's new tax structure are the owners of the large businesses that are separate or support the financial service based businesses. This is because they do not have to pay any corporation tax but will still benefit from the island's business.<ref>8 March 2005 Proposition P44/2005: [http://www.statesassembly.gov.je/documents/propositions/14968-27446-832005.htm Fiscal Strategy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928030501/http://www.statesassembly.gov.je/documents/propositions/14968-27446-832005.htm |date=2007-09-28 }}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{refimprove|date=July 2012}} This article details the variety of means of transport in [[Jersey]], Channel Islands. [[File:C'mîn à bike d'la Baie Saint Hélyi Jèrri.jpg|thumb|Cycle lane in St Helier]] ==Air transport== '''[[Airport]]s:''' *[[Jersey Airport]] ==Rail transport== [[File:Jersey Railway map.png|thumb|Map of the former railway lines of Jersey]] Historically there were public [[railway]] services in the island, provided by two railway companies: *The [[Jersey Railway]] (closed in 1936) *The [[Jersey Eastern Railway]] (closed in 1929). The mostly coastal lines operated out of St Helier and ran across the southern part of the island, reaching [[Gorey, Jersey|Gorey Harbour]] in the east and [[la Corbière]] in the west. There were two stations in St Helier: {{rws|St Helier (Weighbridge)}} (JR) and {{rws|St Helier (Snow Hill)}} (JER). After closure, most of the infrastructure was removed and today little evidence remains of these railways. A small number of former station buildings are still standing, including St Helier Weighbridge, which is now in use as the [[Liberty Wharf]] shopping centre, and [[St Aubin railway station]], which is used today as the Parish Hall of [[Saint Brélade]]. Part of the former Jersey Railway line from St Aubin to Corbière has been converted into a [[rail trail]] for cyclists and walkers. During the [[German occupation of the Channel Islands|German military occupation 1940–1945]], light railways were re-established by the Germans for the purpose of supplying coastal fortifications. A one-metre gauge line was laid down following the route of the former Jersey Railway from Saint Helier to [[La Corbière]], with a branch line connecting the stone quarry at Ronez in [[Saint John, Jersey|Saint John]]. A 60cm line ran along the west coast, and another was laid out heading east from Saint Helier to [[Gorey, Jersey|Gorey]]. The first line was opened in July 1942, the ceremony being disrupted by passively resisting Jersey spectators.Cruickshank, Charles G. (1975) ''The German Occupation of the Channel Islands'', The Guernsey Press, {{ISBN|0-902550-02-0}} The German railway infrastructure was dismantled after the Liberation in 1945. Two railways operate at the [[Pallot Heritage Steam Museum]]; a standard gauge heritage steam railway, and a narrow gauge pleasure line operated by steam-outline diesel motive power. ==Road transport== {{main|Roads in Jersey}} '''[[Highway]]s:'''
''total:'' 577 km (1995)
''paved:'' NA km
''unpaved:'' NA km === Buses === {{main|LibertyBus}} [[File:LibertyBus in Jersey.JPG|thumb|A double-decker bus in St. Brelade, Jersey]] Buses are operated by CT Plus Jersey, a local subsidiary of [[HCT Group]]. Bus service routes radiate from the Liberation Station in St Helier. In 2012, it was announced that [[CT Plus]] would take over the operation of the bus service, commencing on 2 January 2013, ending 10 years of Connex service in Jersey. This new service is called [[LibertyBus]]. ===Cycling=== Jersey has a well sign posted Island Cycle Network. A [[Trail|traffic-free route for cyclists and pedestrians]] links Saint Helier to [[La Corbière]] and a branch of this route ends up at St Peter's village passing Jersey Airport. ===Driving=== [[File:Jersey Traffic-Sign »Green Lane«.Jpg|thumb|A ''green lane'' sign.|upright]] [[File:License plate of Jersey (UK).jpg|200px|thumb|Jersey vehicle number plate]] Driving is on the left hand side. The maximum speed limit throughout the entire island is 40 mph (64 km/h), with slower limits on certain stretches of road, such as 20/30 mph (32/48 km/h) in built up areas and 15 mph (24 km/h) on roads designated as ''green lanes''. Visitors wishing to drive must possess a Certificate of Insurance or an International Green Card, a valid Driving Licence or International Driving Permit (UK International Driving Permits are not valid). Photocopies are not acceptable. A nationality plate must be displayed on the back of visiting vehicles. It is an offence to hold a mobile phone whilst driving a moving vehicle. Where fitted, all passengers inside a vehicle must wear a seat belt at all times, regardless of whether they are sitting in the front or the rear. The penalties for drinking and driving in Jersey are up to £2,000 fine or 6 months in prison for the first offence plus unlimited disqualification of driving licence. It is an offence to drive whilst under the influence of drugs. Since July 2014 it has also been illegal to smoke in any vehicle carrying passengers under the age of 18. {{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-28305726|title=Smoking banned in cars with children|author=|date=15 July 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} ===Parking=== Single yellow lines indicate that parking is prohibited and is liable to a fine. Paycards are used to pay for parking throughout Jersey with the exception of the harbour, airport and waterfront car parks where a pay upon exit scheme is operated. Paycards require scratching off the appropriate day, date, month, and time. Payment by paycards is required for parking wherever the paycard symbol is displayed. Some paycard locations, such as the lay-bys in Victoria Avenue, and car parks in St Brelade's Bay are seasonal. There are four main residents’ and business parking zones within St Helier.[http://www.sthelier.je/residentsparking/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503000913/http://www.sthelier.je/residentsparking/ |date=3 May 2012 }} In some roads on the outskirts of St Helier and in the harbours, and also in some car parks in St Brelade, parking is free but controlled by [[parking disc]]s (time wheels) – obtainable from the Town Hall for a small charge. ==Sea transport== [[File:Noirmont Tower - geograph.ci - 37.jpg|thumb|right|A [[Condor Ferries]] catamaran heading west around Jersey past [[La Tour de Vinde]], Saint Brelade]] '''[[Seaport]]s and [[harbour]]s:''' [[Saint Helier]] is the island's main port, others include [[Gorey, Jersey|Gorey]], [[Saint Aubin, Jersey|Saint Aubin]], [[Vingtaine de la Rocque|La Rocque]], and [[Bonne Nuit (Jersey)|Bonne Nuit]]. It is {{convert|33.6|mi}} distant from [[Granville, Manche]], {{convert|142.9|mi}} from [[Southampton]], {{convert|131.3|mi}} from [[Poole]], and {{convert|22.9|mi}} from [[St Malo]]. On 20 August 2013, [[Huelin-Renouf]], which had operated a "lift-on lift-off" container service for 80 years between the [[Port of Southampton]] and the Port of [[Jersey]], ceased trading.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-23766025|title=Shipping company stops trading|author=|date=20 August 2013|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} Senator [[Alan J.H. Maclean|Alan Maclean]], a Jersey politician had previously tried to save the 90-odd jobs furnished by the company to no avail.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-23737973|title=Shipping company at risk of closure|author=|date=17 August 2013|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} On 20 September, it was announced that [[Channel Island Lines]] would continue this service, and would purchase the MV ''[[Huelin Dispatch]]'' from [[Associated British Ports]] who in turn had purchased them from the receiver in the bankruptcy.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-24176612|title=New freight company for islands|author=|date=20 September 2013|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} The new operator was to be funded by [[Rockayne Limited]], a closely held association of Jersey businesspeople. Passenger-only access to France is provided by [[:fr:Finist'mer|Manche-Iles Express]] ferry service, to either [[Barneville-Carteret]], [[Granville, Manche|Granville]] or [[Flamanville, Manche|Dielette]]. A service to [[St Malo]] was provided by [[:fr:Compagnie nationale de navigation|Compagnie Corsaire]], but is now operated by its sister service, [[Condor Ferries]], which runs ''[[Commodore Goodwill]]'', a large [[Roll-on/roll-off|ro-ro]] vessel to [[Portsmouth]], and has multiple ro-ro connections to [[Poole]] and [[St Malo]]. *[[Poole]] - Guernsey - Jersey (seasonal service normally operated by ''Condor Liberation'') *[[Portsmouth]] - Guernsey - Jersey (''Commodore Clipper'', ''Commodore Goodwill''. {{URL|https://www.fws.gov/refuge/Johnston_Atoll/|www.fws.gov/refuge/Johnston_Atoll/}} | footnotes = }} '''Johnston Atoll''', also known as '''Kalama Atoll''' to [[Native Hawaiians]], is an [[Unincorporated territories of the United States|unincorporated territory]] of the [[United States]] currently administered by the [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service]]. Johnston Atoll is a National Wildlife Refuge and is closed to public entry. Limited access for management needs is only by Letter of Authorization from the U.S. Air Force and Special Use Permit from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. For nearly 70 years, the atoll was under the control of the [[United States Armed Forces|U.S. military]]. During that time, it was variously used as a naval refueling depot, an [[Johnston Island Air Force Base|airbase]], a nuclear and biological weapons testing site, a secret missile base, and a chemical weapon and [[Agent Orange]] storage and disposal site. These activities left the area environmentally contaminated and remediation and monitoring continue. ==Geography== [[File:Midway.jpg|thumb|Johnston Atoll is located between the Marshall Islands and the Hawaiian Islands]] The Johnston Atoll is a deserted {{convert|1300|ha|adj=mid}} [[atoll]] in the [[Pacific Ocean|North Pacific Ocean]] located about {{convert|750|nmi|lk=on}} southwest of the island of Hawai'i and is grouped as one of the [[United States Minor Outlying Islands]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/um.html|title=United States Pacific Island Wildlife Refuges|publisher=|accessdate=September 17, 2014}} The atoll, which is located on a [[coral reef]] platform, has four islands. Johnston (or Kalama) Island and Sand Island are both enlarged natural features, while ''Akau'' (North) and ''Hikina'' (East) are two [[artificial island]]s formed by coral [[dredging]]. By 1964, dredge and fill operations had increased the size of Johnston Island to {{convert|596|acres|abbr=on}} from its original {{convert|46|acre||abbr=on}}, also increased Sand Island from {{convert|10|to|22|acre|abbr=on}}, and added two new islands, North and East, of {{convert|25|and|18|acres|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.fws.gov/refuge/Johnston_Atoll/about.html|title=Fish and Wildlife Service-Johnston Atoll, About the Refuge|publisher=|accessdate=September 17, 2014}} The four islands compose a total land area of {{convert|2.67|km2|abbr=off|sp=us}}. Due to the atoll's tilt, much of the reef on the southeast portion has subsided. But even though it does not have an encircling reef crest, the reef crest on the northwest portion of the atoll does provide for a shallow [[lagoon]], with depths ranging from {{convert|3|-|10|m|ft|abbr=on}}. The climate is tropical but generally dry. Northeast trade winds are consistent and there is little seasonal temperature variation. With elevation ranging from sea level to {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}} at Summit Peak, the islands contain some low-growing vegetation and palm trees on mostly flat terrain and no natural fresh water resources. {|class="wikitable" style="background:#CCC" !Island !Size in
